headline: How a Trump presidency would impact Big Tech
summary: Following Donald Trump's victory in the 2024 US presidential election, tech CEOs were quick to send congratulatory messages. However, Sherwood Senior Correspondent Ronnie Molla suggests this public show of support was more calculated than genuine. "It's like they all prompted ChatGPT for the same response to publicly and then privately talk to Trump," Molla told Catalysts. She notes this was quite different from the tech leaders' reactions to Trump's 2016 win as CEOs now understand from his first presidency that he is capable of "hold[ing] a grudge" or being "very vindictive." Molla singles out Tesla (TSLA) and Elon Musk's related companies, saying they "stand to gain" from Trump's return to the White House due to Musk's deep involvement in the former president's reelection efforts. However, for the broader tech sector, she cautions that the landscape remains "so uncertain" given Trump's potential policies around China tariffs and AI regulation. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Catalysts here. This post was written by Angel Smith

headline: Exclusive-Amazon developing driver eyeglasses to shave seconds off deliveries, sources say
summary: (Reuters) -Amazon is developing smart eyeglasses for its delivery drivers to guide them to, around and within buildings, as it tries to smooth the final stretch of an order's journey to a customer's home, five people familiar with the matter said.  With millions of packages delivered daily, seconds add up.  The glasses would also free drivers from using handheld Global Positioning System devices, allowing them to carry more packages.

headline: India to summon Amazon, Flipkart executives as regulatory scrutiny grows, source says
summary: India's financial crime agency will summon Flipkart and Amazon executives as it steps up an investigation into alleged foreign investment law violations, days after raiding some of the e-commerce firms' sellers, a senior government source said.  The planned action signals growing regulatory scrutiny of Walmart-owned Flipkart and Amazon when their sales are rapidly growing in India's $70 billion e-commerce market.  An Indian antitrust investigation also found the two companies breached laws by favouring select sellers, Reuters has reported.
